Robust core−shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br as synergetic catalyst for chemical fixation of CO2 without co-catalysts Na Wei Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition a Lin Liu Validation Methodology Funding acquisition Formal analysis c Jia-Qi Chu Investigation Data curation c Ting Fang Investigation Data curation c Zheng-Bo Han Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization c ⁎ Zhen Zhao Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization a b ⁎ a Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang, Liaoning 110034, China Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shenyang Normal University Shenyang Liaoning 110034 China aInstitute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University, Shenyang, Liaoning 110034, China b State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum Beijing 102249 China bState Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, China c College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang, Liaoning 110036, China College of Chemistry Liaoning University Shenyang Liaoning 110036 China cCollege of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang, Liaoning 110036, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are widely studied for cycloaddition of CO2 as a heterogeneous catalyst, because of their potential Lewis acidic sites and adjustable porous structure. However, most of them exhibit good catalytic performance need the assistance of nucleophilic co-catalysts. Herein, a novel MOFs and porous organic polymers (POPs) hybrid catalyst, core-shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br, is constructed by a convenient synthetic strategy, which possesses abundant Lewis acidic sites, imidazole cations and nucleophilic centers and shows robust chemical and thermal stability. This material demonstrates high-efficient catalytic activities and recyclability in the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide without co-catalysts, the conversion and selectivity can reach 94.1 % and 99.0 %, respectively (100 °C, 1.0 MPa CO2 pressure). Furthermore, the effects of the temperature, pressure, amount of catalyst and thickness of POPs shell on the catalytic activity were investigated. This study provides a viable direction for the development of synergistic heterogeneous catalysts for fixation of CO2 without co-catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Core-shell structure MOFs POPs Cycloaddition of CO2 Heterogeneous catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the unprecedented large-scale continuous consumption of fossil fuels and the continuous reduction of green plants, the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere has risen sharply, bringing about a series of environmental problems such as rising sea levels, abnormal weather and increasing desertification areas [1,2]. At present, the conversion of CO2 into valuable products is a promising and feasible way to reduce the massive consumption of fossil fuels, thereby reducing the greenhouse effect [3,4]. At the same time, as a kind of C1 raw material with abundant reserves, CO2 has the characteristics of non-toxic, low price, and provides potential convenient applications for chemical absorption and fixation [5,6]. Due to the wide application of cyclic carbonates, the reaction of inserting CO2 into epoxides to generate cyclic carbonates has become a hot arena in the field of chemical absorption and fixation of CO2 in recent years [7–9]. It is generally believed that the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts with Lewis acidic sites and nucleophilic centers is a prerequisite for the CO2 cycloaddition [10,11]. As a new type of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are formed by the metal ions or clusters and organic ligands. Due to large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, clear pore structure and multiple chemical functions, MOFs have been proved to be the ideal heterogeneous catalysts [12–15]. Because of the existence of coordinated unsaturated metal sites as Lewis acidic sites, many MOFs have been successfully used as heterogeneous catalysts in CO2 cycloaddition reactions [16–21]. ZIF-67 has a high surface area that endows ZIF-67 with abundant active sites, and the presence of micropores is favorable for reactions due to their strong affinity for guest molecules [22]. However, most MOF catalytic systems require co-catalysts, such as tetraalkyl ammonium halides, which complicate the separation and purification process due to their homogeneous nature. In recent years, scholars have turned their attention to multifunctional materials with multiple active sites. Among them, the core-shell structured MOF materials have better catalytic performance. Because they possess a stable shell to protect the poorly stable core. Porous organic polymers (POPs) with a large specific surface area, a rich multi-level pore structure and excellent thermal stability are amorphous polymer materials produced by solvothermal polymerization of compounds containing covalent bonds [23,24]. Due to these advantages, compared with traditional inorganic porous materials, POPs provide unprecedented possibilities for heterogeneous catalysis [25,26]. Hence, inspired by the above considerations and our previous works [27–33], we report a novel MOF@POP hybrid material by introducing PDB-Br into the pre-synthesized ZIF-67, called ZIF-67@PDB-Br. Notably, the designed ZIF-67@PDB-Br combines the characteristics of hierarchical porous structure and high nitrogen content. Because of the synergistic effect of the abundant open metal sites, imidazole cations, and nucleophilic groups, the heterogeneous ZIF-67@PDB-Br possesses excellent catalytic performance in the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides, with a conversion and selectivity as high as 94.1 and 99.9 %, respectively, under solvent-free and co-catalysts-free conditions. In addition, there is no significant loss of catalytic activity after six cycles, indicating that the catalytic system has excellent thermal and structural stability. Therefore, this work provides a new porous heterogeneous catalyst for the application of CO2 conversion under solvent-free and co-catalysts-free conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), 2-methylimidazole, 1-vinylimidazole, p-xylylene dibromide, Divinylbenzene (DVB) and 2,2-Azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN) were all purchased from Aladdin (China). Toluene, diethyl ether, methanol, ethanol, ethyl acetate (EtOAc), acetonitrile (MeCN), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were all purchased from the Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (China). All the chemicals and solvents were used without further purification in this study. 2.2 Characterization The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 on a Nicolet 5DX spectrometer and. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was taken on a Perkin-Elmer Pyrisl (25–800 °C, 5 °C min−1, flowing N2 (g)). N2 and CO2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out on an automated gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments ASiQC and BeiShiDe Instrument BSD-PS). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was recorded with a Bruker AXS D8 advanced automated diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were performed on a Hitachi SU8010 system. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G2 F30, FEI Holland microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were taken on a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope. Elemental mapping patterns were carried out on a FEI-Talos-F200X microscope. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer. Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Py-IR) spectra were collected on a PE FT-IR Frontier spectrometer. The products of catalysis reaction were monitored by gas chromatography with a SP-2100A gas chromatograph. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was collected on a Hitachi SU8010 scanning electron microscope equipped with an EDS spectrometer. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP) was performed using a 700 Series ICPOES (Agilent Technologies). 2.3 Preparation of ZIF-67 The synthesis of ZIF-67 was according to the previously reported literature [34]. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.64 g, 5.64 mmol) was first dissolved in 80 mL of methanol. A mixture of 2-methylimidazole (3.70 g, 44.0 mmol) and 80 mL methanol was then added to the above solution under vigorous stirring for 24 h. Finally, the purple product precipitate formed at the end of the reaction was collected by centrifugation, washed with methanol several times, and dried overnight at 60 °C. Before use, the sample was vacuum dried at 100 °C for 5 h to remove the solvent. 2.4 Preparation of PDB-Br The synthesis of PDB-Br was according to the previously reported literature with modification (Scheme S1) [35]. A solution of p-xylylene dibromide (S1) (2.64 g, 0.0100 mol) and 1-vinylimidazole (S2) (1.98 g, 0.0210 mol) in toluene (10.0 mL) was heated in an oil bath at 120 °C for 24 h with magnetic stirring. After cooling at room temperature, the mixture was filtered and washed with diethyl ether several times to obtain the pure BVI-Br. Next, DVB (244 mg, 1.87 mmol) and BVI-Br (530 mg, 1.25 mmol) were added to a solution containing AIBN (10.0 mg, 0.0600 mmol) and ethanol (15.0 mL). After stirring at room temperature for 30 min, the mixture was hydrothermally treated at 70 °C for 24 h. Then filtered and washed with DMF, EtOAc, THF and MeCN three times, followed by drying at 65 oC for 12h. 2.5 Preparation of ZIF-67@PDB-Br The resulting ZIF-67@PDB-Br composite was synthesized by introducing ZIF-67 into the reaction system of the synthesis of PDB-Br. The mixture was instead of DVB (244 mg, 1.87 mmol), BVI-Br (530 mg, 1.25 mmol) and ZIF-67 (350 mg) to add to a solution containing AIBN (10.0 mg, 0.0600 mmol) and ethanol (15.0 mL). 2.6 General procedure for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides Before the reaction, the catalyst was activated under vacuum at 120 oC for 12 h to remove the residual solvent molecules on surface of ZIF-67@PDB-Br. The corresponding epoxide (16.0 mmol) and catalyst (50.0 mg) were introduced into a stainless steel autoclave (20.0 mL). Then CO2 was added until the internal pressure of the system reached the desired pressure at 25 oC and the resulting reaction mixture was stirred at the desired temperature. After 12 h, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and the samples of the reaction mixture were analyzed by GC–MS (GCMS-QP2010) to determine the conversion rate. After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed abundantly with methanol. Then, the washed catalyst was dried under vacuum overnight for the reuse experiments. 2.7 Leaching test The ZIF-67@PDB-Br was separated from the reaction mixture at 100 °C after 4 h. The filtrate was divided into two parts: one was further heated at 100 °C for 8 h and the other part was analyzed by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The synthesis process of core-shell MOF@POP catalyst is displayed in Scheme 1 , the ZIF-67@PDB-Br composite material was synthesized by introducing ZIF-67 into the synthesis process of the PDB-Br, which includes the directed growth of PDB-Br on the surface of ZIF-67 by a polymerization reaction. After PDB-Br is formed on the surface of ZIF-67, the color of the sample has become a lighter purple than ZIF-67 (Fig. S1). First, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis of the as-synthesized samples were conducted to investigate the structure of ZIF-67@PDB-Br. The crystalline structures of ZIF-67, PDB-Br and core–shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br were confirmed by the PXRD (Fig. 1 a). Only a broad peak is observed in the PXRD pattern of PDB-Br indicates the lack of crystalline phases for this POP material. The diffraction peaks of as-synthesized ZIF-67 is exactly consistent with the simulated ZIF-67 pattern, proved the crystalline ZIF-67 was obtained successfully [36]. The almost overlapped peaks in XRD patterns of ZIF-67 and core–shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br demonstrated that the PDB-Br as hybridized materials have no impact on the crystalline structure of the core ZIF-67 [37]. The FT-IR spectrum of ZIF-67@PDB-Br was shown in Fig. 1b, the characteristic absorption peaks at 1142 cm−1, 1417 cm−1, 1628 cm−1 and 3134 cm−1 correspond to the skeleton stretching vibration and NH in-plane vibration of imidazole ring, respectively [34]. Compared to the initial ZIF-67, an emerging peak at 800 cm−1 can be perceived in the FT-IR spectrum of the hybrid ZIF-67@PDB-Br, which is assigned to the out of plane bending vibration of p-disubstituted CH on the benzene ring in PDB-Br. In addition, three new peaks at 1485, 1510 and 1600 cm−1 corresponding to the C = C stretching of the benzene ring in PDB-Br also appear in FT-IR spectrum of ZIF-67@PDB-Br. The IR characteristic peaks of ZIF-67 and PDB-Br can be found in the spectrum of ZIF-67@PDB-Br, confirming that the as-synthesized sample contains both ZIF-67 and PDB-Br species. Subsequently, other characterizations were performed to further substantiates the successful acquisition of ZIF-67@PDB-Br hybrid materials. The morphology of the as-synthesized ZIF-67@PDB-Br was examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM), high resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM). As shown in Fig. 2 a, ZIF-67 shows a dodecahedron-like morphology with a smooth surface and a uniform average size in the range of 400±100 nm. The bare PDB-Br possesses a wrinkle-like morphology with an irregular shape and the size in the micrometer level (Fig. 2b). The SEM image of ZIF-67@PDB-Br reveals that evenly distributed PDB-Br particles are attached to the surface of ZIF-67, with an average particle size of 400–600 nm. After coating, the typical sample ZIF-67@PDB-Br still maintains the morphology of ZIF-67, but the surface is significantly rougher (Fig. 2c). Since the electron penetration of ZIF-67 and PDB-Br components are different, the core-shell interface can be clearly observed. The HAADF-STEM and HR-TEM images further demonstrate that PDB-Br is evenly distributed on the surface of ZIF-67 and the hybrid material has a core-shell structure with an average thickness of 20 nm (Fig. 2d, 2e). The element mapping image shows that N, O, Co, and Br are densely distributed throughout the sample, which further verifies the successful incorporation of different catalytic components. The result of Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) shows that the average content of Br is about 3.11 wt%, which is comparable to the calculated value 2.72 wt%. The thickness of coating shell has a great influence on the formation of core-shell nanostructures. When the precursor concentration is high, the thickness of the shell increases (∼50 nm), which is recorded as ZIF-67@PDB-Br (thick) (Fig. 2f). Whereas, only part of the ZIF-67 nanoparticles is covered when the concentration of PDB-Br precursor is low, and denoted as ZIF-67@PDB-Br (thin), in which the thickness of the shell is about 10 nm (Fig. 2g). To further verify the composition of the as-synthesized sample, the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed to explore the elemental composition and chemical states. The survey spectra for ZIF-67@PDB-Br is shown in Fig. S2 and displays the Co 2p, C 1 s, N 1 s, O 1 s, and Br 3d peaks. The high-resolution Co 2p spectrum (Fig. 3 a) can be deconvoluted into two strong peaks at 781.3 and 796.6 eV, which are assigned to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks, respectively, and two shakeup satellites [38]. The separation between the main peaks and the satellites is about 6 eV, which confirmed that the cobalt ions in ZIF-67 are divalent and the valence states did not change after recombination [39]. The deconvoluted peaks of the C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3b) with binding energies of 285.7 and 284.7 eV of ZIF-67@PDB-Br are assigned to CN and CC bonds, respectively [40,41]. The N 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3c) shows two peaks located at around 401.2 and 398.9 eV, which are related to the contribution of PDB-Br imidazolium N cations (IM-N +) and non-ionic N atoms in the ZIF-67 imidazolium ring (IM-N), respectively [42,43]. The existence of Br 3d signal in XPS spectrum (Fig. 3d, 69.3 eV 3d3/2 and 68.0 eV 3d5/2, respectively) confirmed that the ionic polymer PDB-Br has been successful loaded onto the pure ZIF-67 surface [44]. In order to identify porous characteristics of the as-prepared samples, N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was performed at 77 K (Fig. 4 a). The BET surface areas of bare ZIF-67, PDB-Br and ZIF-67@PDB-Br were measured as 1395 m2g−1, 218 m2g−1, and 628 m2g−1, respectively. The value of BET for ZIF-67@PDB-Br is much higher than its parent PDB-Br and significantly lower than that of pure ZIF-67. This phenomenon has been observed previously [45,46], which can be attributed to the strong interaction during the formation of PDB-Br and the introduction of high atomic mass element Br ions [47–50]. The CO2 adsorption properties of ZIF-67@PDB-Br also been investigated. As shown in Fig. 4b, the CO2 sorption capacities of ZIF-67@PDB-Br with a significantly lower surface area (18 cm3g−1 at 298 K and 33 cm3g−1 at 273 K, 100 kPa) are slightly lower than ZIF-67 (20 cm3g−1 at 298 K and 37 cm3g−1 at 273 K, 100 kPa). The unexpected CO2 adsorption capacity of ZIF-67@PDB-Br is contributed to the nucleophilic species introduced in with the ionic polymer PDB-Br [51], and its core-shell structure which would enhance the adsorbate-surface interactions between the composite and both sides or ends of the CO2 molecules [52]. The isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) of ZIF-67@PDB-Br and ZIF-67 were calculated based on the CO2 adsorption isotherms at 273 K and 298 K using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation [53], clearly gives the Qst values of ZIF-67@PDB-Br and ZIF-67 at zero surface coverage are 25.5 kJ mol−1 and 24.3 kJ mol−1, respectively (Fig. 4c), which reveal that ZIF-67@PDB-Br and ZIF-67 exhibit the similar affinity to CO2 molecules. Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Py-IR) spectroscopy (Fig. 4d) was performed to confirm the existence of Lewis acidic sites. The characteristic peaks of 1450 cm−1 and 1605 cm−1 are all in close agreement with the existence of Lewis acidic sites in ZIF-67@PDB-Br. The acidic property of pure ZIF-67 also been studied by pyridine adsorption experiment, and the spectrum is similar to ZIF-67@PDB-Br. It is assumed that the Lewis acidic sites of the hybrid material originate from parent ZIF-67. The above results further confirmed that the acidic sites of ZIF-67 in the hybrid material ZIF-67@PDB-Br were completely retained. The number of acidic sites is determined using the peak (1450 cm−1) areas at pyridine sorption. The peak areas of pyridine adsorption in ZIF-67 and ZIF-67@PDB-Br are 31.573 and 24.152, respectively, and the number of Lewis acid sites in ZIF-67 and ZIF-67@PDB-Br is 378.84 mmol g −1 and 289.79 mmol g −1, respectively. The smaller number of acidic sites of ZIF-67@PDB-Br should be because the content of ZIF-67 in hybrid material is lower than that in pure ZIF-67 for the sample with same mass. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed to determine the thermal stability of ZIF-67@PDB-Br. As shown in Fig. S3, the first weight losses of ZIF-67 [54] (∼10 %, below 450 °C), PDB-Br (∼5 %, below 200 °C) and ZIF-67@PDB-Br (∼13 %, below 200 °C) are assigned to the removal of guest molecules in the samples. With the increase of the corresponding temperatures, the structures of these samples began to collapse. For PDB-Br, the decomposition of ionic polymer can be divided into two steps: the disintegration of the grafted ionic liquids between 200 and 320 °C (∼15 %), and the collapse of the polymer matrix between 320 and 800 °C. For ZIF-67@PDB-Br, the weight loss from 200 °C to 450 °C belongs to decomposition of PDB-Br coating (∼42 %), and the weight loss above 450 °C is derived from the decomposition of both the PDB-Br and ZIF-67 species in the hybrid sample [55]. In conclusion, the pristine ZIF-67 shows better thermal stability than the hybrid material ZIF-67@PDB-Br, which can be attributed to the fact that the polymer coating (PDB-Br) of the core-shell hybrid material begins to decompose at lower temperatures. To further determine the chemical stability, ZIF-67@PDB-Br were soaked in aqueous solutions with different pH values. The PXRD patterns (Fig. S4) and FT-IR spectra (Fig. S5) of ZIF-67@PDB-Br after soaking in aqueous solutions with pH=7 and 12 for 24 h are consistent with the as-synthesized one, indicating that no framework collapse or phase transition occurs in water and basic solutions. However, after soaking in aqueous solutions pH = 2 for 24 h, the most of sample dissolved and the PXRD patterns of the remaining solid exhibit obvious changes, indicating the ZIF-67@PDB-Br is not resistant to acid. 3.2 Catalytic performances The conversion of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) to propylene carbonate (PC) was selected as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of ZIF-67@PDB-Br as a catalyst, the results are summarized in Table 1 . The yield for PC for the conversion of PO reached 94.1 % when ZIF-67@PDB-Br was used as the catalyst at 100 °C (Table 1, entries 3–5). Comparably, the independent ZIF-67 or PDB-Br demonstrated lower catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of PO and CO2 (Table 1, entries 1 and 2) under the same conditions, indicating that both ZIF-67 and PDB-Br play predominant roles in the reaction. The control experiments mentioned above show that the core-shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br as a catalyst can significantly improve the efficiency of the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. To address the necessity of chemical grafting between the shell and core in ZIF-67@PDB-Br, a physical mixture of ZIF-67 and PDB-Br, consisting of the same loading amount of bromide as that in ZIF-67@PDB-Br, was subsequently examined (Table 1, entry 11). The obtained conversion (87.5 %) suggested the presence of the cooperative effect of Lewis acidic sites and the nucleophile Br−, which improved the catalytic performance of the system [56]. Inspired by the excellent catalytic performance of cycloaddition of CO2, we also investigated the catalytic activity of ZIF-67@PDB-Br under atmospheric pressure. Surprisingly, a PC yield of 90.8 % can be obtained at 100 °C, 0.1 MPa and 24 h (Table 1, entry 10), further proof of the excellent synergy. The yield for PC is 41.7 % when was used ZIF-67@PDB-Br (thin) as the catalyst (Table 1, entry 6). This may be related to the lack of imidazole groups and bromide ions. In addition, when was used ZIF-67@PDB-Br (thick) as the catalyst, the conversion is 36.0 %, because the presence of a large amount of PDB-Br prevents the reactants to enter the pores of ZIF-67 (Table 1, entry 7). In general, the experimental results demonstrate that the ZIF-67@PDB-Br system has an excellent catalytic activity for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with PO. Furthermore, we investigated the influence of reaction temperature, reaction time and the amount of catalysts on the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with PO. As shown in Table 1 (entries 3–5), when the reaction temperature is changed from 60 °C to 100 °C, the results show that the temperature change has a great influence on the yield of the catalytic reaction. This can be attributed to the increase in the number of active molecules as the temperature increases, and effective collisions between the catalyst and the substrate. The dependence of PC yield on reaction time was also explored. As time increases, PC yield gradually increased in the first 10 h. When the reaction time was extended for another 2 h, the PC yield increased relatively slowly (Fig. S3). Nevertheless, when the amount of catalyst was increased from 30 mg to 40 mg, the yield of PC increased from 55.6 % to 77.5 % (Table 1, entries 8–9), indicating that the amount of catalyst had a positive effect on the PC yield. The kinetics of CO₂ cycloaddition to propylene oxide (PO) were investigated using a previously reported method [57,58]. The general rate equation for the cycloaddition reaction is represented in Eq. (1), where k is the rate constant and [PO], [CO2], [catalysts] denote the concentrations of PO, CO2 and the catalysts (ZIF-67@PDB-Br, PDB-Br and ZIF-67), respectively; a, b and c are the orders of reaction. For each experiment, the concentration of catalysts remains constant throughout the reaction, and the CO2 is present in large excess, so the concentration of CO2 also could be considered as constant. Therefore, the Eq. (1) could be simplified as Eq. (2). The kobs is the observed rate constant of CO2 cycloaddition to PO. From Eq. (2) it is clear that the rate of reaction depends only on the concentration of PO hence the reaction kinetic is determined only with respect to the substrate PO. By integrating Eq. (2), the Eq. (4) was obtained which can be used to determine the order of reaction with respect to [PO]. Given that the reaction temperature (100 °C) is significantly above the boiling point of PO, the gas phase in the reaction system is a mixture of CO₂ and PO. In addition, the reaction between PO and CO₂ is stoichiometric, so the PO concentration can be tracked by monitoring the changes of system pressure (Fig. S6). Assuming ideal gas behavior, Eq. (5) is derived, leading to Eq. (6). The decrease of PO concentration can be calculated using Eq. (6). (1) R a t e = k [ P O ] a [ C O 2 ] b [ c a t a l y s t s ] c (2) R a t e = k o b s [ P O ] a = − d [ P O ] d t where (3) k o b s = k [ C O 2 ] b [ c a t a l y s t s ] c (4) − ln [ P O ] = k o b s t (5) P V = n R T (6) 2 Δ n P O = V R T Δ P To determine the reaction kinetics, three set of reactions were carried out, which catalyzed by ZIF-67@PDB-Br, PDB-Br and ZIF-67, respectively. The time-dependent PO concentrations were obtained by recording pressure changes over time in these reactions, and the first-order model is used to determine the reaction kinetics. As shown in Fig. S7, the model fits the data well. Thus, the reaction follows pseudo-first-order kinetics with reasonable rate constant (0.0295 h −1, 0.0173 h −1 and 0.0088 h −1, corresponding to ZIF-67@PDB-Br, PDB-Br and ZIF-67, respectively). A comparison of the rate constants for the three catalysts indicates that the core-shell structure of ZIF-67@PDB-Br significantly improves the kinetics of the cycloaddition reaction. The heterogeneous catalytic performance of the ZIF-67@PDB-Br catalyst in the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO was studied by leaching test. After 4 h of reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction system, and the reaction was continued for 8 h without the catalyst. It is observed that the yield of PC remains unchanged (51.0 %), which means that the catalyst is completely heterogeneous during the reaction (Fig. S8). Considering the heterogeneous nature of the catalyst, the reusability and stability of the catalyst in the cycloaddition reaction were evaluated under the optimal reaction conditions. The results show that after sixth cycle, the catalytic activity of ZIF-67@PDB-Br is still comparable to that of the freshly prepared for the cycloaddition of CO2 and PO (Fig. S9). Moreover, the SEM (Fig. S10) image, PXRD pattern (Fig. S11) and FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S12) of the recycled ZIF-67@PDB-Br catalyst also confirmed that after the catalytic experiment, the morphology and structural integrity are well maintained. Motivated by the above encouraging results, a series of substrates for the synthesis of various cyclic carbonates under the optimized conditions were investigated. Table 2 displays the yield and turnover numbers (TON) of various cyclic carbonates synthesized from their respective epoxide substrates. All epoxides can be converted into corresponding cyclic carbonates with high selectivity and no obvious by-products are observed. When small epoxides are used as substrates, they are almost quantitatively converted into cyclic carbonates. With the extension of epoxide substituent chain, the yields of the reaction decreased significantly. The yields of chloroethylene carbonate, butylene carbonate, styrene carbonate and 3-butoxy-1,2-propylene carbonate were 93.0 %, 86.0 %, 63.0 % and 56.0 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 2–5). The yields of larger substituents were found to decrease (Table 2, entries 4–5), which may be the reason for the slow diffusion of the large-sized substrates into the void spaces of the framework. The TON value was calculated based on the amount of Co sites in ZIF-67@PDB-Br catalyst (88.5 mg/L), which was confirmed by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. The catalytic activity of ZIF-67@PDB-Br catalyst in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction were also compared to the some reported nucleophilic-functionalized MOFs-based catalysts and the results are presented in Table S1. For example, compared with Fe-MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br (Table S1, entry 1 and 2), ZIF-67@PDB-Br can obtain the similar cyclic carbonate yield in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction of PO or ECH with less dosage under milder reaction conditions. For the ionic liquid functionalized UiO-66 materials, ZnTCPP⊂(Br−)Etim-UiO-66 (Table S1, entry 6) and (I −)Meim-UiO-66 (Table S1, entry 7 and 8), less ZIF-67@PDB-Br can achieve the higher conversion of PO or ECH under the equivalent reaction condition. Although the CO2 cycloaddition reaction of ECH catalyzed by ZIF-67@PDB-Br obtains a equal yield to the one catalyzed by polyILs@MIL-101 (Table S1, entry 17) under more harsh conditions, the reaction time is shorter and the amount of catalyst is reduced greatly (nearly 16 times). For other catalysts listed in Table S1, the ZIF-67@PDB-Br also exhibit certain advantages in terms of reaction time, reaction conditions, amounts of catalyst or the yield of cyclic carbonates, which make it more competitive. Based on previous reports and our current observations [59–62], we have proposed a synergistic mechanism for chemical fixation CO2 into cyclic carbonates in the presence of the core-shell catalyst composed of electrophilic Lewis acidic sites, imidazole cations and nucleophilic halogen anions (Fig. 5 ). Firstly, The Co-O coordination bond is formed between epoxide and Lewis acidic Co sites, leading to the activation of the epoxide. Simultaneously, the nucleophilic Br− anions attack the β-C atom with less steric hindrance of epoxide, and ring opening reaction takes place to form bromoalkoxylates. Meanwhile, the CO2 activated by the imidazole cationic group is rapidly inserted into the ring-opening Co-O bond [63], and finally the reaction is completed through the intramolecular ring-closing step to obtain the cyclic carbonate and the regenerated catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, a core-shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br catalyst has been constructed by introduction POP containing the imidazole cationic group and the nucleophilic Br− into the pre-synthesized ZIF-67 via a convenient synthetic strategy, which was successfully used as a highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for producing the cyclic carbonates under solvent-free and co-catalysts-free conditions. The catalyst ZIF-67@PDB-Br offered excellent catalytic performance for catalyzing the coupling of CO2 with PO, e.g., the high yields of 94.1 % for propylene carbonate (PC) was obtained at 100 °C and 1.0 MPa. Furthermore, it has good tolerance to a series of epoxides and can be reused for six cycles without significant loss of catalytic activity and selectivity. The high efficiency of ZIF-67@PDB-Br is mainly attributed to open metal Co sites, imidazole cations and halogen anions. This work provides a new kind of multifunctional MOF@POP heterogeneous catalyst for highly efficient chemical fixation of CO2 without adding any co-catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are widely studied for cycloaddition of CO2 as a heterogeneous catalyst, because of their potential Lewis acidic sites and adjustable porous structure. However, most of them exhibit good catalytic performance need the assistance of nucleophilic co-catalysts. Herein, a novel MOFs and porous organic polymers (POPs) hybrid catalyst, core-shell ZIF-67@PDB-Br, is constructed by a convenient synthetic strategy, which possesses abundant Lewis acidic sites, imidazole cations and nucleophilic centers and shows robust chemical and thermal stability. This material demonstrates high-efficient catalytic activities and recyclability in the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide without co-catalysts, the conversion and selectivity can reach 94.1 % and 99.0 %, respectively (100 °C, 1.0 MPa CO2 pressure). Furthermore, the effects of the temperature, pressure, amount of catalyst and thickness of POPs shell on the catalytic activity were investigated. This study provides a viable direction for the development of synergistic heterogeneous catalysts for fixation of CO2 without co-catalysts.
